trustfund:
TF054602-PHRD-MOLDOVA: COMPETITIVENESS
            ENHANCEMENT PROJECT,TF055175-PHRD-MOLDOVA: COMPETITIVENESS
            ENHANCEMENT PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Competitiveness
            Enhancement Project for Moldova were as follows: outcomes
            were satisfactory, risk to development outcome was
            negligible, Bank performance was satisfactory, and Borrower
            performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            given the sustained high degree of Borrower's ownership
            of and commitment to the program, even a very complex and
            ambitious program can be implemented successfully. The
            selection of two professional organizations (chamber of
            commerce and industry (CCI) and credit line directorate
            (CLD)) to administer the matching grant facility (MGF) and
            the line of credit operation (LOC) went a long way to ensure
            successful implementation. The government must be commended
            for utilizing project funds to hire such competent agencies.
            The project design should have taken into consideration the
            complexity and time required in procuring complex machinery
            which was to be installed in existing refurbished buildings.
            It is recommended that the Bank, in collaboration with the
            counterparts, invest more time in planning complex project
            activities (such as high precision metrological instruments
            and the facilities to house them), involving relevant
            technical experts and allowing for an adequate timeframe,
            avoiding delays that were experienced under the project.
            While the MGF component was successful overall, the
            component can have had a greater impact if it were not for
            constraints on timelines presented by the way in which the
            MGF administrator's CCI contract was handled. The main
            essential components for a successful private sector
            development (PSD) project which focuses on small and medium
            enterprises (SMEs) in a country the size of Moldova can be
            considered to have: (i) proper regulatory reforms for a
            better business environment and ease of doing business; (ii)
            upgrading of the metrology, standardization, testing, and
            quality (MSTQ) systems to gain access to foreign markets and
            boosting competitiveness; and (iii) access to finance and
            technology services. Well-functioning implementation unit,
            staffed with competent and committed people and fairly
            remunerated is essential for a successful implementation of
            a multi-component and a complex project.
